choices.C: You can export them to be used in other ADOMs.
choices.D: You can use them as variables in scripts.
choices.A: You can invoke them using the $ character.
choices.B: You can add them to objects as custom attributes.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

An administrator created two new meta fields in FortiManager.
Which operation can be performed with these parameters?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The Answer is B - Meta Fields can added as custom attributes to objects on FortiManager. 
This should not be confused with ADOM level Metadata variables. Meta Fields cannot be used as variables in scripts or provision templates, for this you need to use metada variables on ADOM-Level, as stated on page 181 in the 7.4 Study guide.

Selected Answer: B
Correct Answer: B.
FortiManager 7.4 Administrator Study Guide
B it's OK

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
FMG 7.4 Administrator Study Guide

Selected Answer: B

It only reloads FortiManagerâ€™s internal database for that device, which may help fix issues with display, status, or synchronization problems.

Selected Answer: B
Correct answer: B

choices.A: It compares and provides differences in configuration on FortiManager with the current running configuration of the specified FortiGate.
choices.B: It downloads the latest configuration from the specified FortiGate and performs a reload operation on the device database.
choices.C: It reloads the policy package from the FortiManager to FortiGate.
choices.D: It installs the latest configuration on the specified FortiGate and updates the revision history database.

questions.question_text:
An administrator runs the reload failure command diagnose test deploymanager reloadconf <deviceid> on FortiManager.
What does this command do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correct Answer is A
Adom in 7.2 can managed Fortigate in version 7.0, 7.2 and 7.4
A as it is compatible

choices.B: Adding higher version FortiGate devices to a lower version ADOM triggers an automatic ADOM upgrade.
choices.A: The ADOM can concurrently manage FortiGate devices running different firmware versions.
choices.C: The ADOM restricts access to devices running lower firmware versions.
choices.D: Upgrading the FortiGate devices to FortiOS 7.4 may result in ADOM database corruption.

questions.question_text: What happens if you create an ADOM with version 7.2, add FortiGate devices running FortiOS 7.2, and then upgrade the FortiGate devices to FortiOS 7.4?

discussion.content: B. FortiManager installs the default value if there is no reference.

Selected Answer: B

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

An administrator has created a firewall address object that is used in multiple policy packages for multiple FortiGate devices in an ADOM.
After the installation operation is performed, which IP/netmask is shown on FortiManager for this firewall address object for devices without a Per-Device Mapping set?

choices.D: FortiManager replaces the address object to none.
choices.A: FortiManager generates an error for each FortiGate without a per-device mapping defined for that object.

choices.C: The customer administrator can unassign the policy by locking My_ADOM.
choices.B: The customer administrator can unassign the global policy from My_ADOM.
choices.A: The service provider administrator can unassign the global policy from My_ADOM.
choices.D: The service provider administrator can unassign the policy from the global ADOM.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

A service provider administrator has assigned a global policy package to a managed customer ADOM named My_ADOM, which has four policy packages. The customer administrator has access only to My_ADOM.
How can the customer or service provider administrators remove the global header policy from the policy package named Shared_Package?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
For me, it's A. D can't be correct as it suggest you can unassign only the policy from Global ADOM. You can't unassign only one or several policy. Only assign/unassign entire policy package

B is wrong as customer administrator don't have right permission to unassign global policy package (see question context)
C is wrong as there is no link between locking an ADOM and remove a policy
D is wrong as user have right permissions but you can't unassign one or specific policy

Selected Answer: B
The customer administrator can only modify policies within their assigned ADOM (My_ADOM) and cannot remove a global header policy unless it is explicitly part of their Shared_Package in that ADOM.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
I think it is D
